Award.AwardTitle: A computational framework for atherosclerotic plaque growth simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigators develop a computational framework for the growth of atherosclerotic plaques in large arteries. Specific emphasis is placed on the nonlinear constitutive models for the arterial wall, including residual stresses, and on the bridging of the highly separated time scales that govern this process. This study focuses on the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations that describe the blood flow, coupled with nonlinear elasticity equations that govern the response of the diseased arterial walls. The actual plaque growth process exhibits a large separation of time scales between the growth of the plaque, which takes place over a course of years, and the heart rate, which is in the order of seconds. The investigators develop a methodology to couple a growth model with the fluid-structure interaction problem in a way that the fundamental challenges incurred by the separation of time scales are resolved. In addition, the computational framework allows for the incorporation of variable behavioral factors, such as physical activity and cholesterol concentration in the blood.

While it is known that the rupturing of an atherosclerotic plaque can cause a heart attack, the actual growth process of plaques in arteries is far from well understood. In this project, a computational framework is developed that bridges the highly separated time scales between the plaque growth and the heart rate, and that allows for the incorporation of accurate models for the elastic arterial walls. This new framework can yield fundamental insights into the long-term causes of atherosclerosis, and the dependence of the disease on behavioral factors such as physical activity, cholesterol intake, and tobacco use. In addition, the methodologies developed in this project can find applications in the modeling of damage in elastic materials, other diseases that develop over a large time span such as abdominal aortic aneurysms and intimal hyperplasia, and biological phenomena such as the growth and transport of algae in channel flows and the growth of biofilms. This project involves a collaboration with engineers who measure residual stresses in arteries experimentally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has focused on computational models for the growth of atherosclerotic plaques, and it has provided insight into the mechanisms of the growth of those plaques in arteries. A key challenge in the simulation of atherosclerosis is that the growth happens on a time scale of years; but it is affected by the blood flow and pulsatile motion, which happen on time scales of seconds. This research focused on computational approaches to bridge these vastly different time scales, and to give rise to efficient computational models and methods. One key insight obtained from the modeling and simulations conducted in this project is that ripples that are observed on the surface of real plaques can actually be explained as stemming from an instability in the growth process. Those ripples are likely playing a relevant role in the medical relevance of plaques (robustness, risk of rupture, etc.). Therefore, an explanation of their origin may impact future medical research.

The Intellectual Merit of this research lies in (a) the development of computational methodologies that bridge the time scales in fluid-structure interaction and moving boundary problems; and (b) the finding that surface structures of plaques can be linked to fundamental mathematical properties of nonlinear surface diffusion-advection-reaction models.

The Broader Impacts stem from the fact that atherosclerotic plaques play a central role in many cardiovascular diseases that affect a substantial number of humans over the course of the aging of their bodies. In addition to the medical relevance of the structural insights, the computational models and methods studied and proposed in this project may also apply to a number of other physical and biological phenomena exhibit similar phenomena, for example damage in elastic materials, biofilms, tumor growth, epithelial cells, etc.

Products created in this project that go beyond journal publications are the training of an early career researcher and an undergraduate student research project.
